title: Saturday Night Live Midweek Sketch: Austin Butler Gets a Reality Check
description: In this midweek sketch ahead of this weekend's year-ender, Saturday Night Live host Austin Butler's SNL dreams get a bit of a reality check.
author: Ray Flook
excerpt: It's the middle of the week, which means it's time for the newest weekly tradition to take the main stage of NBC's Saturday Night Live. That's right, it's the midweek sketch. With Austin Butler (Elvis) hosting and musical guest Lizzo ready to tear up our screens one more time, we're getting a chance to check […]
text: Posted in: NBC, Preview, TV, YouTube | Tagged: Austin Butler, lizzo, nbc, preview, saturday night live, snlIt's the middle of the week, which means it's time for the newest weekly tradition to take the main stage of NBC's Saturday Night Live. That's right, it's the midweek sketch. With Austin Butler (Elvis) hosting and musical guest Lizzo ready to tear up our screens one more time, we're getting a chance to check out Butler as he takes it all in. What with being a first-timer and all of the historic pressure that comes from hosting… right? Of course, it doesn't take long before those lofty dreams receive a bit of a reality check… Image: NBC Screencap Here's a look at Butler getting ready for his first time hosting SNL, followed by a look back at how the week's gone so far (with read-thru images expected later today): Now here's a look back at the official SNL "welcome" video for Butler & Lizzo from earlier in the week, followed by a rundown of this season's cast and a look back at some thoughts that SNL creator Lorne Michaels had to share prior to Season 48: NBC's SNL Season 48 includes Michael Che, Mikey Day, Andrew Dismukes, Chloe Fineman, Heidi Gardner, Marcello Hernandez, James Austin Johnson, Punkie Johnson, Colin Jost, Molly Kearney, Michael Longfellow, Ego Nwodim, Sarah Sherman, Cecily Strong, Kenan Thompson, Devon Walker, and Bowen Yang. Executive produced by Michaels, SNL is directed by Liz Patrick, with alum Darrell Hammond announcing. Based out of Studio 8H in Rockefeller Center, the long-running late-night sketch comedy/music series is produced by SNL Studios in association with Universal Television and Broadway Video. Image: NBC Lorne Michaels on Saturday Night Live Season 48, SNL's Future & More Speaking with The New York Times, Michaels addressed the casting changes, labeling the upcoming season as "a year of reinvention" that could lead to some "exhilarating" change. He also had some reassuring words for "Weekend Update" fans and teased what's in store for SNL's big 50th-anniversary celebration. Here are some of the highlights: COVID-19 Fallout Resulted in Much Larger SNL Cast Than Usual: "The pandemic had put us in this position where no one could really leave because there were no jobs. And at the same time, if I don't add new people every year, then the show isn't the show. There have to be new people, for both our sake and also for the audience." Michaels Believes Cast Departures are Good Things for SNL: "We got to a point where we had a lot of people, and people weren't getting enough playing time. The way the series has survived is by that level of renewal. The price of success is that people go off and do other things; their primary obligation is to their talent and to keep pushing that. And there's something so much better about the show when all that matters is the show. There's a time to say goodbye, and there's a natural time for it, but the natural time just got interfered with by the pandemic." … Except with Colin Jost, Michael Che & "Weekend Update": "Particularly, coming into a midterm election, I just need that part ['Weekend Update' with Che & Jost] to be as solid as it is." SNL's 50th Anniversary/Season? Think Big: "The 50th will be a big event. We'll bring everyone back from all 50 years and hosts and all of that. It will be a very emotional and very strong thing. There won't be as many plus-ones, I can tell you that much." Enjoyed this? Please share on social media! Stay up-to-date and support the site by following Bleeding Cool on Google News today! About Ray FlookServing as Television Editor since 2018, Ray began five years earlier as a contributing writer/photographer before being brought onto the core BC team in 2017.
html:
Posted in: NBC, Preview, TV, YouTube | Tagged: Austin Butler, lizzo, nbc, preview, saturday night live, snl

It's the middle of the week, which means it's time for the newest weekly tradition to take the main stage of NBC's Saturday Night Live. That's right, it's the midweek sketch. With Austin Butler (Elvis) hosting and musical guest Lizzo ready to tear up our screens one more time, we're getting a chance to check out Butler as he takes it all in. What with being a first-timer and all of the historic pressure that comes from hosting… right? Of course, it doesn't take long before those lofty dreams receive a bit of a reality check…

Here's a look at Butler getting ready for his first time hosting SNL, followed by a look back at how the week's gone so far (with read-thru images expected later today):

Now here's a look back at the official SNL "welcome" video for Butler & Lizzo from earlier in the week, followed by a rundown of this season's cast and a look back at some thoughts that SNL creator Lorne Michaels had to share prior to Season 48:

NBC's SNL Season 48 includes Michael Che, Mikey Day, Andrew Dismukes, Chloe Fineman, Heidi Gardner, Marcello Hernandez, James Austin Johnson, Punkie Johnson, Colin Jost, Molly Kearney, Michael Longfellow, Ego Nwodim, Sarah Sherman, Cecily Strong, Kenan Thompson, Devon Walker, and Bowen Yang. Executive produced by Michaels, SNL is directed by Liz Patrick, with alum Darrell Hammond announcing. Based out of Studio 8H in Rockefeller Center, the long-running late-night sketch comedy/music series is produced by SNL Studios in association with Universal Television and Broadway Video.

Lorne Michaels on Saturday Night Live Season 48, SNL's Future & More

Speaking with The New York Times, Michaels addressed the casting changes, labeling the upcoming season as "a year of reinvention" that could lead to some "exhilarating" change. He also had some reassuring words for "Weekend Update" fans and teased what's in store for SNL's big 50th-anniversary celebration. Here are some of the highlights:

COVID-19 Fallout Resulted in Much Larger SNL Cast Than Usual: "The pandemic had put us in this position where no one could really leave because there were no jobs. And at the same time, if I don't add new people every year, then the show isn't the show. There have to be new people, for both our sake and also for the audience."

Michaels Believes Cast Departures are Good Things for SNL: "We got to a point where we had a lot of people, and people weren't getting enough playing time. The way the series has survived is by that level of renewal. The price of success is that people go off and do other things; their primary obligation is to their talent and to keep pushing that. And there's something so much better about the show when all that matters is the show. There's a time to say goodbye, and there's a natural time for it, but the natural time just got interfered with by the pandemic."

… Except with Colin Jost, Michael Che & "Weekend Update": "Particularly, coming into a midterm election, I just need that part ['Weekend Update' with Che & Jost] to be as solid as it is."

SNL's 50th Anniversary/Season? Think Big: "The 50th will be a big event. We'll bring everyone back from all 50 years and hosts and all of that. It will be a very emotional and very strong thing. There won't be as many plus-ones, I can tell you that much."

Enjoyed this? Please share on social media!

Stay up-to-date and support the site by following Bleeding Cool on Google News today!

About Ray Flook

Serving as Television Editor since 2018, Ray began five years earlier as a contributing writer/photographer before being brought onto the core BC team in 2017.
